      83             : /* This list of SSL3 cipher suites is sorted in descending order of
      84             :  * precedence (desirability).  It only includes cipher suites we implement.
      85             :  * This table is modified by SSL3_SetPolicy(). The ordering of cipher suites
      86             :  * in this table must match the ordering in SSL_ImplementedCiphers (sslenum.c)
      87             :  *
      88             :  * Important: See bug 946147 before enabling, reordering, or adding any cipher

     180             : 
     181             : /* This is the default supported set of signature schemes.  The order of the
     182             :  * hashes here is all that is important, since that will (sometimes) determine
     183             :  * which hash we use.  The key pair (i.e., cert) is the primary thing that
     184             :  * determines what we use and this doesn't affect how we select key pairs.  The
     185             :  * order of signature types is based on the same rules for ordering we use for
     186             :  * cipher suites just for consistency.
     187             :  */
     188             : static const SSLSignatureScheme defaultSignatureSchemes[] = {

     246             :         return PR_TRUE; /* Always enabled */

     248             :     if (ss->sec.isServer) {

     255             :     }
     256             :     if (version >= SSL_LIBRARY_VERSION_TLS_1_3) {
     257             :         return PR_FALSE;

     264             :         return ss->opt.enableDeflate;
     265             :     }
     266             : #endif
     267             :     return PR_FALSE;

     275             : 
     276             : static SSL3Statistics ssl3stats;
     277             : 
     278             : /* Record protection algorithms, indexed by SSL3BulkCipher.
     279             :  *
     280             :  * The |max_records| field (|mr| below) is set to a number that is higher than
     281             :  * recommended in some literature (esp. TLS 1.3) because we currently abort the
     282             :  * connection when this limit is reached and we want to ensure that we only
     283             :  * rarely hit this limit.  See bug 1268745 for details.
     284             :  */
     285             : #define MR_MAX RECORD_SEQ_MAX  /* 2^48-1 */
     286             : #define MR_128 (0x5aULL << 28) /* For AES and similar. */
     287             : #define MR_LOW (1ULL << 20)    /* For weak ciphers. */
     288             : /* clang-format off */
     289             : static const ssl3BulkCipherDef bulk_cipher_defs[] = {
     290             :     /*                                    |--------- Lengths ---------| */
     291             :     /* cipher             calg            :  s                        : */
     292             :     /*                                    :  e                  b     n */
     293             :     /* oid                short_name mr   :                     l     o */
     294             :     /*                                    k  r                  o  t  n */
     295             :     /*                                    e  e               i  c  a  c */
     296             :     /*                                    y  t  type         v  k  g  e */
     297             :     {cipher_null,         calg_null,      0, 0, type_stream, 0, 0, 0, 0,
     298             :      SEC_OID_NULL_CIPHER, "NULL", MR_MAX},
     299             :     {cipher_rc4,          calg_rc4,      16,16, type_stream, 0, 0, 0, 0,
     300             :      SEC_OID_RC4,         "RC4", MR_LOW},
     301             :     {cipher_des,          calg_des,       8, 8, type_block,  8, 8, 0, 0,
     302             :      SEC_OID_DES_CBC,     "DES-CBC", MR_LOW},
     303             :     {cipher_3des,         calg_3des,     24,24, type_block,  8, 8, 0, 0,
     304             :      SEC_OID_DES_EDE3_CBC, "3DES-EDE-CBC", MR_LOW},
     305             :     {cipher_aes_128,      calg_aes,      16,16, type_block, 16,16, 0, 0,
     306             :      SEC_OID_AES_128_CBC, "AES-128", MR_128},
     307             :     {cipher_aes_256,      calg_aes,      32,32, type_block, 16,16, 0, 0,
     308             :      SEC_OID_AES_256_CBC, "AES-256", MR_128},
     309             :     {cipher_camellia_128, calg_camellia, 16,16, type_block, 16,16, 0, 0,
     310             :      SEC_OID_CAMELLIA_128_CBC, "Camellia-128", MR_128},
     311             :     {cipher_camellia_256, calg_camellia, 32,32, type_block, 16,16, 0, 0,
     312             :      SEC_OID_CAMELLIA_256_CBC, "Camellia-256", MR_128},
     313             :     {cipher_seed,         calg_seed,     16,16, type_block, 16,16, 0, 0,
     314             :      SEC_OID_SEED_CBC,    "SEED-CBC", MR_128},
     315             :     {cipher_aes_128_gcm,  calg_aes_gcm,  16,16, type_aead,   4, 0,16, 8,
     316             :      SEC_OID_AES_128_GCM, "AES-128-GCM", MR_128},
     317             :     {cipher_aes_256_gcm,  calg_aes_gcm,  32,32, type_aead,   4, 0,16, 8,
     318             :      SEC_OID_AES_256_GCM, "AES-256-GCM", MR_128},
     319             :     {cipher_chacha20,     calg_chacha20, 32,32, type_aead,  12, 0,16, 0,
     320             :      SEC_OID_CHACHA20_POLY1305, "ChaCha20-Poly1305", MR_MAX},
     321             :     {cipher_missing,      calg_null,      0, 0, type_stream, 0, 0, 0, 0,
     322             :      SEC_OID_UNKNOWN,     "missing", 0U},
     323             : };

     328             :     {kea_null,           ssl_kea_null, nullKey, ssl_auth_null, PR_FALSE, 0},

     338             :     {kea_ecdhe_rsa,      ssl_kea_ecdh, rsaKey, ssl_auth_rsa_sign, PR_TRUE,  SEC_OID_TLS_ECDHE_RSA},
     339             :     {kea_ecdh_anon,      ssl_kea_ecdh, nullKey, ssl_auth_null, PR_TRUE,  SEC_OID_TLS_ECDH_ANON},
     340             :     {kea_ecdhe_psk,      ssl_kea_ecdh_psk, nullKey, ssl_auth_psk, PR_TRUE, SEC_OID_TLS_ECDHE_PSK},
     341             :     {kea_dhe_psk,      ssl_kea_dh_psk, nullKey, ssl_auth_psk, PR_TRUE, SEC_OID_TLS_DHE_PSK},
     342             :     {kea_tls13_any,      ssl_kea_tls13_any, nullKey, ssl_auth_tls13_any, PR_TRUE, SEC_OID_TLS13_KEA_ANY},
     343             : };
     344             : 
     345             : /* must use ssl_LookupCipherSuiteDef to access */
     346             : static const ssl3CipherSuiteDef cipher_suite_defs[] =
     347             : {
     348             : /*  cipher_suite                    bulk_cipher_alg mac_alg key_exchange_alg prf_hash */
     349             : /*  Note that the prf_hash_alg is the hash function used by the PRF, see sslimpl.h.  */
     350             : 
     351             :     {TLS_NULL_WITH_NULL_NULL,       cipher_null,   mac_null, kea_null, ssl_hash_none},
     352             :     {TLS_RSA_WITH_NULL_MD5,         cipher_null,   mac_md5, kea_rsa, ssl_hash_none},

     474             :     SSLCipherAlgorithm calg;
     475             :     CK_MECHANISM_TYPE cmech;

     478             : /* indexed by type SSLCipherAlgorithm */
     479             : static const SSLCipher2Mech alg2Mech[] = {
     480             :     /* calg,          cmech  */
     481             :     { calg_null, (CK_MECHANISM_TYPE)0x80000000L },
     482             :     { calg_rc4, CKM_RC4 },
     483             :     { calg_rc2, CKM_RC2_CBC },
     484             :     { calg_des, CKM_DES_CBC },
     485             :     { calg_3des, CKM_DES3_CBC },

     495             : 
     496             : #define mmech_invalid (CK_MECHANISM_TYPE)0x80000000L
     497             : #define mmech_md5 CKM_SSL3_MD5_MAC
     498             : #define mmech_sha CKM_SSL3_SHA1_MAC
     499             : #define mmech_md5_hmac CKM_MD5_HMAC
     500             : #define mmech_sha_hmac CKM_SHA_1_HMAC
     501             : #define mmech_sha256_hmac CKM_SHA256_HMAC
     502             : #define mmech_sha384_hmac CKM_SHA384_HMAC
     503             : 
     504             : /* clang-format off */
     505             : static const ssl3MACDef mac_defs[] = { /* indexed by SSL3MACAlgorithm */
     506             :     /* pad_size is only used for SSL 3.0 MAC. See RFC 6101 Sec. 5.2.3.1. */
     507             :     /* mac      mmech       pad_size  mac_size                       */
     508             :     { mac_null, mmech_invalid,    0,  0         ,  0},
     509             :     { mac_md5,  mmech_md5,       48,  MD5_LENGTH,  SEC_OID_HMAC_MD5 },
     510             :     { mac_sha,  mmech_sha,       40,  SHA1_LENGTH, SEC_OID_HMAC_SHA1},
     511             :     {hmac_md5,  mmech_md5_hmac,   0,  MD5_LENGTH,  SEC_OID_HMAC_MD5},
     512             :     {hmac_sha,  mmech_sha_hmac,   0,  SHA1_LENGTH, SEC_OID_HMAC_SHA1},
     513             :     {hmac_sha256, mmech_sha256_hmac, 0, SHA256_LENGTH, SEC_OID_HMAC_SHA256},
     514             :     { mac_aead, mmech_invalid,    0,  0, 0 },
     515             :     {hmac_sha384, mmech_sha384_hmac, 0, SHA384_LENGTH, SEC_OID_HMAC_SHA384}
     516             : };

     518             : 
     519             : const PRUint8 tls13_downgrade_random[] = { 0x44, 0x4F, 0x57, 0x4E,
     520             :                                            0x47, 0x52, 0x44, 0x01 };
     521             : const PRUint8 tls12_downgrade_random[] = { 0x44, 0x4F, 0x57, 0x4E,
     522             :                                            0x47, 0x52, 0x44, 0x00 };
     523             : PR_STATIC_ASSERT(sizeof(tls13_downgrade_random) ==
     524             :                  sizeof(tls13_downgrade_random));
     525             : 
     526             : /* The ECCWrappedKeyInfo structure defines how various pieces of
     527             :  * information are laid out within wrappedSymmetricWrappingkey
     528             :  * for ECDH key exchange. Since wrappedSymmetricWrappingkey is
     529             :  * a 512-byte buffer (see sslimpl.h), the variable length field
     530             :  * in ECCWrappedKeyInfo can be at most (512 - 8) = 504 bytes.
     531             :  *
     532             :  * XXX For now, NSS only supports named elliptic curves of size 571 bits
     533             :  * or smaller. The public value will fit within 145 bytes and EC params
     534             :  * will fit within 12 bytes. We'll need to revisit this when NSS
     535             :  * supports arbitrary curves.
     536             :  */
     537             : #define MAX_EC_WRAPPED_KEY_BUFLEN 504
     538             : 
     539             : typedef struct ECCWrappedKeyInfoStr {
     540             :     PRUint16 size;                          /* EC public key size in bits */
     541             :     PRUint16 encodedParamLen;               /* length (in bytes) of DER encoded EC params */
     542             :     PRUint16 pubValueLen;                   /* length (in bytes) of EC public value */
     543             :     PRUint16 wrappedKeyLen;                 /* length (in bytes) of the wrapped key */
     544             :     PRUint8 var[MAX_EC_WRAPPED_KEY_BUFLEN]; /* this buffer contains the */
     545             :     /* EC public-key params, the EC public value and the wrapped key  */
     546             : } ECCWrappedKeyInfo;
     547             : 
     548             : CK_MECHANISM_TYPE
     549           1 : ssl3_Alg2Mech(SSLCipherAlgorithm calg)
     550             : {
     551             :     PORT_Assert(alg2Mech[calg].calg == calg);
     552           1 :     return alg2Mech[calg].cmech;
     553             : }
     554             : 
     555             : #if defined(TRACE)
     556             : 
     557             : static char *
     558             : ssl3_DecodeHandshakeType(int msgType)
     559             : {
     560             :     char *rv;
     561             :     static char line[40];
     562             : 
     563             :     switch (msgType) {
     564             :         case hello_request:
     565             :             rv = "hello_request (0)";
     566             :             break;
     567             :         case client_hello:
     568             :             rv = "client_hello  (1)";
     569             :             break;
     570             :         case server_hello:
     571             :             rv = "server_hello  (2)";
     572             :             break;
     573             :         case hello_verify_request:
     574             :             rv = "hello_verify_request (3)";
     575             :             break;
     576             :         case new_session_ticket:
     577             :             rv = "session_ticket (4)";
     578             :             break;
     579             :         case hello_retry_request:
     580             :             rv = "hello_retry_request (6)";
     581             :             break;
     582             :         case encrypted_extensions:
     583             :             rv = "encrypted_extensions (8)";
     584             :             break;
     585             :         case certificate:
     586             :             rv = "certificate  (11)";
     587             :             break;
     588             :         case server_key_exchange:
     589             :             rv = "server_key_exchange (12)";
     590             :             break;
     591             :         case certificate_request:
     592             :             rv = "certificate_request (13)";
     593             :             break;
     594             :         case server_hello_done:
     595             :             rv = "server_hello_done   (14)";
     596             :             break;
     597             :         case certificate_verify:
     598             :             rv = "certificate_verify  (15)";
     599             :             break;
     600             :         case client_key_exchange:
     601             :             rv = "client_key_exchange (16)";
     602             :             break;
     603             :         case finished:
     604             :             rv = "finished     (20)";
     605             :             break;
     606             :         default:
     607             :             sprintf(line, "*UNKNOWN* handshake type! (%d)", msgType);
     608             :             rv = line;
     609             :     }
     610             :     return rv;
     611             : }
     612             : 
     613             : static char *
     614             : ssl3_DecodeContentType(int msgType)
     615             : {
     616             :     char *rv;
     617             :     static char line[40];
     618             : 
     619             :     switch (msgType) {
     620             :         case content_change_cipher_spec:
     621             :             rv = "change_cipher_spec (20)";
     622             :             break;
     623             :         case content_alert:
     624             :             rv = "alert      (21)";
     625             :             break;
     626             :         case content_handshake:
     627             :             rv = "handshake  (22)";
     628             :             break;
     629             :         case content_application_data:
     630             :             rv = "application_data (23)";
     631             :             break;
     632             :         default:
     633             :             sprintf(line, "*UNKNOWN* record type! (%d)", msgType);
     634             :             rv = line;
     635             :     }
     636             :     return rv;
     637             : }
     638             : 
     639             : #endif
     640             : 
     641             : SSL3Statistics *
     642           1 : SSL_GetStatistics(void)
     643             : {
     644           1 :     return &ssl3stats;
     645             : }
     646             : 
     647             : typedef struct tooLongStr {
     648             : #if defined(IS_LITTLE_ENDIAN)
     649             :     PRInt32 low;
     650             :     PRInt32 high;
     651             : #else
     652             :     PRInt32 high;
     653             :     PRInt32 low;
     654             : #endif
     655             : } tooLong;
     656             : 
     657             : void
     658           1 : SSL_AtomicIncrementLong(long *x)
     659             : {
     660             :     if ((sizeof *x) == sizeof(PRInt32)) {
     661             :         PR_ATOMIC_INCREMENT((PRInt32 *)x);
     662             :     } else {
     663           1 :         tooLong *tl = (tooLong *)x;

    1665             : static SECStatus
    1666             : ssl3_DeflateCompress(void *void_context, unsigned char *out, int *out_len,
    1667             :                      int maxout, const unsigned char *in, int inlen)
    1668             : {
    1669             :     z_stream *context = void_context;
    1670             : 
    1671             :     if (!inlen) {
    1672             :         *out_len = 0;
    1673             :         return SECSuccess;
    1674             :     }
    1675             : 
    1676             :     context->next_in = (unsigned char *)in;
    1677             :     context->avail_in = inlen;
    1678             :     context->next_out = out;
    1679             :     context->avail_out = maxout;
    1680             :     if (deflate(context, Z_SYNC_FLUSH) != Z_OK) {
    1681             :         return SECFailure;
    1682             :     }
    1683             :     if (context->avail_out == 0) {
    1684             :         /* We ran out of space! */
    1685             :         SSL_TRC(3, ("%d: SSL3[%d] Ran out of buffer while compressing",
    1686             :                     SSL_GETPID()));
    1687             :         return SECFailure;
    1688             :     }
    1689             : 
    1690             :     *out_len = maxout - context->avail_out;
    1691             :     return SECSuccess;
    1692             : }

    1771             : 
    1772             : /* ssl3_BuildRecordPseudoHeader writes the SSL/TLS pseudo-header (the data
    1773             :  * which is included in the MAC or AEAD additional data) to |out| and returns
    1774             :  * its length. See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5246#section-6.2.3.3 for the
    1775             :  * definition of the AEAD additional data.
    1776             :  *
    1777             :  * TLS pseudo-header includes the record's version field, SSL's doesn't. Which
    1778             :  * pseudo-header defintiion to use should be decided based on the version of
    1779             :  * the protocol that was negotiated when the cipher spec became current, NOT
    1780             :  * based on the version value in the record itself, and the decision is passed
    1781             :  * to this function as the |includesVersion| argument. But, the |version|
    1782             :  * argument should be the record's version value.
    1783             :  */
    1784             : static unsigned int
    1785           1 : ssl3_BuildRecordPseudoHeader(unsigned char *out,
    1786             :                              sslSequenceNumber seq_num,
    1787             :                              SSL3ContentType type,
    1788             :                              PRBool includesVersion,
    1789             :                              SSL3ProtocolVersion version,
    1790             :                              PRBool isDTLS,
    1791             :                              int length)
    1792             : {
    1793           1 :     out[0] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 56);
    1794           1 :     out[1] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 48);
    1795           1 :     out[2] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 40);
    1796           1 :     out[3] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 32);
    1797           1 :     out[4] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 24);
    1798           1 :     out[5] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 16);
    1799           1 :     out[6] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 8);
    1800           1 :     out[7] = (unsigned char)(seq_num >> 0);
    1801           1 :     out[8] = type;
    1802             : 
    1803             :     /* SSL3 MAC doesn't include the record's version field. */
    1804           1 :     if (!includesVersion) {
    1805           0 :         out[9] = MSB(length);
    1806           0 :         out[10] = LSB(length);
    1807           0 :         return 11;
    1808             :     }
    1809             : 
    1810             :     /* TLS MAC and AEAD additional data include version. */
    1811           1 :     if (isDTLS) {
    1812             :         SSL3ProtocolVersion dtls_version;
    1813             : 
    1814           1 :         dtls_version = dtls_TLSVersionToDTLSVersion(version);
    1815           1 :         out[9] = MSB(dtls_version);
    1816           1 :         out[10] = LSB(dtls_version);
    1817             :     } else {
    1818           1 :         out[9] = MSB(version);
    1819           1 :         out[10] = LSB(version);
    1820             :     }
    1821           1 :     out[11] = MSB(length);
    1822           1 :     out[12] = LSB(length);
    1823           1 :     return 13;
    1824             : }
    1825             : 
    1826             : static SECStatus
    1827           1 : ssl3_AESGCM(ssl3KeyMaterial *keys,
    1828             :             PRBool doDecrypt,
    1829             :             unsigned char *out,
    1830             :             int *outlen,
    1831             :             int maxout,
    1832             :             const unsigned char *in,
    1833             :             int inlen,
    1834             :             const unsigned char *additionalData,
    1835             :             int additionalDataLen)

    1837             :     SECItem param;
    1838           1 :     SECStatus rv = SECFailure;

    1842             : 
    1843           1 :     const int tagSize = bulk_cipher_defs[cipher_aes_128_gcm].tag_size;
    1844           1 :     const int explicitNonceLen =
    1845             :         bulk_cipher_defs[cipher_aes_128_gcm].explicit_nonce_size;
    1846             : 
    1847             :     /* See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5288#section-3 for details of how the
    1848             :      * nonce is formed. */
    1849           1 :     memcpy(nonce, keys->write_iv, 4);
    1850           1 :     if (doDecrypt) {
    1851           1 :         memcpy(nonce + 4, in, explicitNonceLen);
    1852           1 :         in += explicitNonceLen;
    1853           1 :         inlen -= explicitNonceLen;
    1854           1 :         *outlen = 0;
    1855             :     } else {
    1856           1 :         if (maxout < explicitNonceLen) {
    1857           0 :             PORT_SetError(SEC_ERROR_INPUT_LEN);
    1858           0 :             return SECFailure;
    1859             :         }
    1860             :         /* Use the 64-bit sequence number as the explicit nonce. */
    1861           1 :         memcpy(nonce + 4, additionalData, explicitNonceLen);

    1863           1 :         out += explicitNonceLen;

    1865           1 :         *outlen = explicitNonceLen;
    1866             :     }
    1867             : 
    1868           1 :     param.type = siBuffer;
    1869           1 :     param.data = (unsigned char *)&gcmParams;

    1875           1 :     gcmParams.ulTagBits = tagSize * 8;

    1881           1 :         rv = PK11_Encrypt(keys->write_key, CKM_AES_GCM, &param, out, &uOutLen,
    1882             :                           maxout, in, inlen);
    1883             :     }

    1885             : 
    1886           1 :     return rv;
    1887             : }

    1889             : static SECStatus
    1890           0 : ssl3_ChaCha20Poly1305(ssl3KeyMaterial *keys, PRBool doDecrypt,

    1938             : /* Initialize encryption and MAC contexts for pending spec.
    1939             :  * Master Secret already is derived.
    1940             :  * Caller holds Spec write lock.
    1941             :  */

    1943           1 : ssl3_InitPendingContexts(sslSocket *ss)

    2071             : 
    2072           1 :     pwSpec->encodeContext = (ss->sec.isServer) ? serverContext : clientContext;

    2074             :

    2081             :

    2543             : 
    2544             : SECStatus
    2545           1 : ssl_ProtectRecord(sslSocket *ss, ssl3CipherSpec *cwSpec,
    2546             :                   PRBool capRecordVersion, SSL3ContentType type,

    2606             :         {
    2607           1 :             *ptr++ = type;

    2624           1 :     ++cwSpec->write_seq_num;
    2625             : 
    2626           1 :     return SECSuccess;
    2627             : }
    2628             : 
    2629             : /* Process the plain text before sending it.
    2630             :  * Returns the number of bytes of plaintext that were successfully sent
    2631             :  *  plus the number of bytes of plaintext that were copied into the
    2632             :  *  output (write) buffer.
    2633             :  * Returns SECFailure on a hard IO error, memory error, or crypto error.
    2634             :  * Does NOT return SECWouldBlock.
    2635             :  *
    2636             :  * Notes on the use of the private ssl flags:
    2637             :  * (no private SSL flags)
    2638             :  *    Attempt to make and send SSL records for all plaintext
    2639             :  *    If non-blocking and a send gets WOULD_BLOCK,
    2640             :  *    or if the pending (ciphertext) buffer is not empty,
    2641             :  *    then buffer remaining bytes of ciphertext into pending buf,
    2642             :  *    and continue to do that for all succssive records until all
    2643             :  *    bytes are used.
    2644             :  * ssl_SEND_FLAG_FORCE_INTO_BUFFER
    2645             :  *    As above, except this suppresses all write attempts, and forces
    2646             :  *    all ciphertext into the pending ciphertext buffer.
    2647             :  * ssl_SEND_FLAG_USE_EPOCH (for DTLS)
    2648             :  *    Forces the use of the provided epoch
    2649             :  * ssl_SEND_FLAG_CAP_RECORD_VERSION
    2650             :  *    Caps the record layer version number of TLS ClientHello to { 3, 1 }
    2651             :  *    (TLS 1.0). Some TLS 1.0 servers (which seem to use F5 BIG-IP) ignore
    2652             :  *    ClientHello.client_version and use the record layer version number
    2653             :  *    (TLSPlaintext.version) instead when negotiating protocol versions. In
    2654             :  *    addition, if the record layer version number of ClientHello is { 3, 2 }
    2655             :  *    (TLS 1.1) or higher, these servers reset the TCP connections. Lastly,
    2656             :  *    some F5 BIG-IP servers hang if a record containing a ClientHello has a
    2657             :  *    version greater than { 3, 1 } and a length greater than 255. Set this
    2658             :  *    flag to work around such servers.
    2659             :  */
    2660             : PRInt32
    2661           1 : ssl3_SendRecord(sslSocket *ss,
    2662             :                 ssl3CipherSpec *cwSpec, /* non-NULL for DTLS retransmits */
    2663             :                 SSL3ContentType type,
    2664             :                 const SSL3Opaque *pIn, /* input buffer */
    2665             :                 PRInt32 nIn,           /* bytes of input */

    2858             : #define SSL3_PENDING_HIGH_WATER 1024

    3844             : /*

    4104           1 : ssl3_UpdateHandshakeHashes(sslSocket *ss, const unsigned char *b, unsigned int l)
    4105             : {
    4106           1 :     SECStatus rv = SECSuccess;
    4107             : 
    4108             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    4109             : 
    4110             :     /* With TLS 1.3, and versions TLS.1.1 and older, we keep the hash(es)
    4111             :      * always up to date. However, we must initially buffer the handshake
    4112             :      * messages, until we know what to do.
    4113             :      * If ss->ssl3.hs.hashType != handshake_hash_unknown,
    4114             :      * it means we know what to do. We calculate (hash our input),
    4115             :      * and we stop appending to the buffer.
    4116             :      *
    4117             :      * With TLS 1.2, we always append all handshake messages,
    4118             :      * and never update the hash, because the hash function we must use for
    4119             :      * certificate_verify might be different from the hash function we use
    4120             :      * when signing other handshake hashes. */
    4121             : 
    4122           1 :     if (ss->ssl3.hs.hashType == handshake_hash_unknown ||
    4123             :         ss->ssl3.hs.hashType == handshake_hash_record) {
    4124           1 :         return sslBuffer_Append(&ss->ssl3.hs.messages, b, l);
    4125             :     }
    4126             : 
    4127             :     PRINT_BUF(90, (NULL, "handshake hash input:", b, l));
    4128             : 
    4129           1 :     if (ss->ssl3.hs.hashType == handshake_hash_single) {
    4130             :         PORT_Assert(ss->version >= SSL_LIBRARY_VERSION_TLS_1_3);

    4132           0 :         if (rv != SECSuccess) {

    4299             : 
    4300             : /**************************************************************************
    4301             :  * Consume Handshake functions.
    4302             :  *
    4303             :  * All data used in these functions is protected by two locks,
    4304             :  * the RecvBufLock and the SSL3HandshakeLock
    4305             :  **************************************************************************/
    4306             : 
    4307             : /* Read up the next "bytes" number of bytes from the (decrypted) input
    4308             :  * stream "b" (which is *length bytes long). Copy them into buffer "v".
    4309             :  * Reduces *length by bytes.  Advances *b by bytes.
    4310             :  *
    4311             :  * If this function returns SECFailure, it has already sent an alert,
    4312             :  * and has set a generic error code.  The caller should probably
    4313             :  * override the generic error code by setting another.
    4314             :  */
    4315             : SECStatus
    4316           1 : ssl3_ConsumeHandshake(sslSocket *ss, void *v, PRUint32 bytes, SSL3Opaque **b,
    4317             :                       PRUint32 *length)
    4318             : {
    4319             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveRecvBufLock(ss));
    4320             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    4321             : 
    4322           1 :     if ((PRUint32)bytes > *length) {
    4323           0 :         return ssl3_DecodeError(ss);
    4324             :     }
    4325           1 :     PORT_Memcpy(v, *b, bytes);
    4326             :     PRINT_BUF(60, (ss, "consume bytes:", *b, bytes));
    4327           1 :     *b += bytes;
    4328           1 :     *length -= bytes;
    4329           1 :     return SECSuccess;
    4330             : }
    4331             : 
    4332             : /* Read up the next "bytes" number of bytes from the (decrypted) input
    4333             :  * stream "b" (which is *length bytes long), and interpret them as an
    4334             :  * integer in network byte order.  Sets *num to the received value.
    4335             :  * Reduces *length by bytes.  Advances *b by bytes.
    4336             :  *
    4337             :  * On error, an alert has been sent, and a generic error code has been set.
    4338             :  */
    4339             : SECStatus
    4340           1 : ssl3_ConsumeHandshakeNumber(sslSocket *ss, PRUint32 *num, PRUint32 bytes,
    4341             :                             SSL3Opaque **b, PRUint32 *length)
    4342             : {
    4343           1 :     PRUint8 *buf = *b;
    4344             :     int i;
    4345             : 
    4346             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveRecvBufLock(ss));
    4347             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    4348             : 
    4349           1 :     *num = 0;
    4350           1 :     if (bytes > *length || bytes > sizeof(*num)) {
    4351           0 :         return ssl3_DecodeError(ss);
    4352             :     }
    4353             :     PRINT_BUF(60, (ss, "consume bytes:", *b, bytes));
    4354             : 
    4355           1 :     for (i = 0; i < bytes; i++) {
    4356           1 :         *num = (*num << 8) + buf[i];
    4357             :     }
    4358           1 :     *b += bytes;
    4359           1 :     *length -= bytes;
    4360           1 :     return SECSuccess;
    4361             : }
    4362             : 
    4363             : /* Read in two values from the incoming decrypted byte stream "b", which is
    4364             :  * *length bytes long.  The first value is a number whose size is "bytes"
    4365             :  * bytes long.  The second value is a byte-string whose size is the value
    4366             :  * of the first number received.  The latter byte-string, and its length,
    4367             :  * is returned in the SECItem i.
    4368             :  *
    4369             :  * Returns SECFailure (-1) on failure.
    4370             :  * On error, an alert has been sent, and a generic error code has been set.
    4371             :  *
    4372             :  * RADICAL CHANGE for NSS 3.11.  All callers of this function make copies
    4373             :  * of the data returned in the SECItem *i, so making a copy of it here
    4374             :  * is simply wasteful.  So, This function now just sets SECItem *i to
    4375             :  * point to the values in the buffer **b.
    4376             :  */
    4377             : SECStatus

    4522             : /* Validate that the signature scheme works for the given key.

    4933             : 
    4934             : static const char *
    4935             : ssl_ClientHelloTypeName(sslClientHelloType type)
    4936             : {
    4937             :     switch (type) {
    4938             :         CHTYPE(initial);
    4939             :         CHTYPE(retry);
    4940             :         CHTYPE(retransmit);    /* DTLS only */
    4941             :         CHTYPE(renegotiation); /* TLS <= 1.2 only */
    4942             :     }
    4943             :     PORT_Assert(0);
    4944             :     return NULL;
    4945             : }
    4946             : #undef CHTYPE
    4947             : #endif
    4948             : 
    4949             : /* Called from ssl3_HandleHelloRequest(),
    4950             :  *             ssl3_RedoHandshake()
    4951             :  *             ssl_BeginClientHandshake (when resuming ssl3 session)
    4952             :  *             dtls_HandleHelloVerifyRequest(with resending=PR_TRUE)
    4953             :  *
    4954             :  * The |type| argument indicates what is going on here:
    4955             :  * - client_hello_initial is set for the very first ClientHello
    4956             :  * - client_hello_retry indicates that this is a second attempt after receiving
    4957             :  *   a HelloRetryRequest (in TLS 1.3)
    4958             :  * - client_hello_retransmit is used in DTLS when resending
    4959             :  * - client_hello_renegotiation is used to renegotiate (in TLS <1.3)
    4960             :  */
    4961             : SECStatus
    4962           1 : ssl3_SendClientHello(sslSocket *ss, sslClientHelloType type)

    5642             :              * we do an ECDH computation involving this public key and
    5643             :              * the SSL server's (long-term) EC private key. The resulting

    5744             : SECStatus
    5745           1 : ssl_InitSymWrapKeysLock(void)
    5746             : {
    5747           1 :     symWrapKeysLock = PZ_NewLock(nssILockOther);
    5748           1 :     return symWrapKeysLock ? SECSuccess : SECFailure;
    5749             : }
    5750             : 
    5751             : /* Try to get wrapping key for mechanism from in-memory array.
    5752             :  * If that fails, look for one on disk.
    5753             :  * If that fails, generate a new one, put the new one on disk,
    5754             :  * Put the new key in the in-memory array.
    5755             :  *
    5756             :  * Note that this function performs some fairly inadvisable functions with
    5757             :  * certificate private keys.  ECDSA keys are used with ECDH; similarly, RSA
    5758             :  * signing keys are used to encrypt.  Bug 1248320.
    5759             :  */
    5760             : PK11SymKey *
    5761           0 : ssl3_GetWrappingKey(sslSocket *ss,
    5762             :                     PK11SlotInfo *masterSecretSlot,
    5763             :                     CK_MECHANISM_TYPE masterWrapMech,
    5764             :                     void *pwArg)
    5765             : {
    5766             :     SSLAuthType authType;
    5767             :     SECKEYPrivateKey *svrPrivKey;
    5768           0 :     SECKEYPublicKey *svrPubKey = NULL;
    5769           0 :     PK11SymKey *unwrappedWrappingKey = NULL;
    5770             :     PK11SymKey **pSymWrapKey;
    5771           0 :     CK_MECHANISM_TYPE asymWrapMechanism = CKM_INVALID_MECHANISM;

    6693             : #ifndef TLS_1_3_DRAFT_VERSION
    6694             :     /* Check the ServerHello.random per
    6695             :      * [draft-ietf-tls-tls13-11 Section 6.3.1.1].
    6696             :      *
    6697             :      * TLS 1.3 clients receiving a TLS 1.2 or below ServerHello MUST check
    6698             :      * that the top eight octets are not equal to either of these values.
    6699             :      * TLS 1.2 clients SHOULD also perform this check if the ServerHello
    6700             :      * indicates TLS 1.1 or below.  If a match is found the client MUST
    6701             :      * abort the handshake with a fatal "illegal_parameter" alert.
    6702             :      *
    6703             :      * Disable this test during the TLS 1.3 draft version period.
    6704             :      */

    6706             :                                                            : ss->vrange.max;

    7710             : /* Called from ssl3_HandleServerHelloDone and ssl3_AuthCertificateComplete.
    7711             :  *
    7712             :  * Caller must hold Handshake and RecvBuf locks.
    7713             :  */
    7714             : static SECStatus
    7715           1 : ssl3_SendClientSecondRound(sslSocket *ss)
    7716             : {
    7717             :     SECStatus rv;
    7718             :     PRBool sendClientCert;
    7719             : 
    7720             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveRecvBufLock(ss));
    7721             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    7722             : 
    7723           1 :     sendClientCert = !ss->ssl3.sendEmptyCert &&
    7724           1 :                      ss->ssl3.clientCertChain != NULL &&
    7725           1 :                      ss->ssl3.clientPrivateKey != NULL;
    7726             : 
    7727             :     /* We must wait for the server's certificate to be authenticated before
    7728             :      * sending the client certificate in order to disclosing the client
    7729             :      * certificate to an attacker that does not have a valid cert for the
    7730             :      * domain we are connecting to.
    7731             :      *
    7732             :      * XXX: We should do the same for the NPN extension, but for that we
    7733             :      * need an option to give the application the ability to leak the NPN
    7734             :      * information to get better performance.
    7735             :      *
    7736             :      * During the initial handshake on a connection, we never send/receive
    7737             :      * application data until we have authenticated the server's certificate;
    7738             :      * i.e. we have fully authenticated the handshake before using the cipher
    7739             :      * specs agreed upon for that handshake. During a renegotiation, we may
    7740             :      * continue sending and receiving application data during the handshake
    7741             :      * interleaved with the handshake records. If we were to send the client's
    7742             :      * second round for a renegotiation before the server's certificate was
    7743             :      * authenticated, then the application data sent/received after this point
    7744             :      * would be using cipher spec that hadn't been authenticated. By waiting
    7745             :      * until the server's certificate has been authenticated during
    7746             :      * renegotiations, we ensure that renegotiations have the same property
    7747             :      * as initial handshakes; i.e. we have fully authenticated the handshake
    7748             :      * before using the cipher specs agreed upon for that handshake for
    7749             :      * application data.
    7750             :      */
    7751           1 :     if (ss->ssl3.hs.restartTarget) {
    7752             :         PR_NOT_REACHED("unexpected ss->ssl3.hs.restartTarget");
    7753           0 :         PORT_SetError(SEC_ERROR_LIBRARY_FAILURE);
    7754           0 :         return SECFailure;
    7755             :     }
    7756           1 :     if (ss->ssl3.hs.authCertificatePending &&
    7757           1 :         (sendClientCert || ss->ssl3.sendEmptyCert || ss->firstHsDone)) {
    7758             :         SSL_TRC(3, ("%d: SSL3[%p]: deferring ssl3_SendClientSecondRound because"
    7759             :                     " certificate authentication is still pending.",
    7760             :                     SSL_GETPID(), ss->fd));
    7761           1 :         ss->ssl3.hs.restartTarget = ssl3_SendClientSecondRound;
    7762           1 :         return SECWouldBlock;
    7763             :     }
    7764             : 
    7765           1 :     ssl_GetXmitBufLock(ss); /*******************************/
    7766             : 
    7767           1 :     if (ss->ssl3.sendEmptyCert) {
    7768           1 :         ss->ssl3.sendEmptyCert = PR_FALSE;

    7770             :         /* Don't send verify */
    7771           1 :         if (rv != SECSuccess) {
    7772             :             goto loser; /* error code is set. */
    7773             :         }

    8038             :     }

    8040             : }
    8041             : 
    8042             : /* Select a cipher suite.
    8043             : **
    8044             : ** NOTE: This suite selection algorithm should be the same as the one in
    8045             : ** ssl3_HandleV2ClientHello().
    8046             : **
    8047             : ** If TLS 1.0 is enabled, we could handle the case where the client
    8048             : ** offered TLS 1.1 but offered only export cipher suites by choosing TLS
    8049             : ** 1.0 and selecting one of those export cipher suites. However, a secure
    8050             : ** TLS 1.1 client should not have export cipher suites enabled at all,
    8051             : ** and a TLS 1.1 client should definitely not be offering *only* export
    8052             : ** cipher suites. Therefore, we refuse to negotiate export cipher suites
    8053             : ** with any client that indicates support for TLS 1.1 or higher when we
    8054             : ** (the server) have TLS 1.1 support enabled.
    8055             : */
    8056             : SECStatus
    8057           1 : ssl3_NegotiateCipherSuite(sslSocket *ss, const SECItem *suites,
    8058             :                           PRBool initHashes)
    8059             : {
    8060             :     int j;
    8061             :     int i;
    8062             : 
    8063           1 :     for (j = 0; j < ssl_V3_SUITES_IMPLEMENTED; j++) {
    8064           1 :         ssl3CipherSuiteCfg *suite = &ss->cipherSuites[j];
    8065           1 :         SSLVersionRange vrange = { ss->version, ss->version };
    8066           1 :         if (!config_match(suite, ss->ssl3.policy, &vrange, ss)) {
    8067           1 :             continue;
    8068             :         }
    8069           0 :         for (i = 0; i + 1 < suites->len; i += 2) {
    8070           1 :             PRUint16 suite_i = (suites->data[i] << 8) | suites->data[i + 1];
    8071           1 :             if (suite_i == suite->cipher_suite) {
    8072           1 :                 return ssl3_SetCipherSuite(ss, suite_i, initHashes);
    8073             :             }
    8074             :         }
    8075             :     }
    8076             :     return SECFailure;
    8077             : }

    9825             : 
    9826             : /* find a slot that is able to generate a PMS and wrap it with RSA.
    9827             :  * Then generate and return the PMS.
    9828             :  * If the serverKeySlot parameter is non-null, this function will use
    9829             :  * that slot to do the job, otherwise it will find a slot.
    9830             :  *
    9831             :  * Called from  ssl3_DeriveConnectionKeys()  (above)
    9832             :  *      ssl3_SendRSAClientKeyExchange()     (above)
    9833             :  *      ssl3_HandleRSAClientKeyExchange()  (below)
    9834             :  * Caller must hold the SpecWriteLock, the SSL3HandshakeLock
    9835             :  */
    9836             : static PK11SymKey *
    9837           0 : ssl3_GenerateRSAPMS(sslSocket *ss, ssl3CipherSpec *spec,
    9838             :                     PK11SlotInfo *serverKeySlot)
    9839             : {
    9840           0 :     PK11SymKey *pms = NULL;
    9841           0 :     PK11SlotInfo *slot = serverKeySlot;
    9842           0 :     void *pwArg = ss->pkcs11PinArg;
    9843             :     SECItem param;
    9844             :     CK_VERSION version;
    9845             :     CK_MECHANISM_TYPE mechanism_array[3];
    9846             : 
    9847             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    9848             : 
    9849           0 :     if (slot == NULL) {
    9850             :         SSLCipherAlgorithm calg;
    9851             :         /* The specReadLock would suffice here, but we cannot assert on
    9852             :         ** read locks.  Also, all the callers who call with a non-null
    9853             :         ** slot already hold the SpecWriteLock.
    9854             :         */
    9855             :         PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSpecWriteLock(ss));
    9856             :         PORT_Assert(ss->ssl3.prSpec == ss->ssl3.pwSpec);
    9857             : 
    9858           0 :         calg = spec->cipher_def->calg;
    9859             : 
    9860             :         /* First get an appropriate slot.  */
    9861           0 :         mechanism_array[0] = CKM_SSL3_PRE_MASTER_KEY_GEN;
    9862           0 :         mechanism_array[1] = CKM_RSA_PKCS;
    9863           0 :         mechanism_array[2] = ssl3_Alg2Mech(calg);
    9864             : 
    9865           0 :         slot = PK11_GetBestSlotMultiple(mechanism_array, 3, pwArg);
    9866           0 :         if (slot == NULL) {
    9867             :             /* can't find a slot with all three, find a slot with the minimum */
    9868           0 :             slot = PK11_GetBestSlotMultiple(mechanism_array, 2, pwArg);
    9869           0 :             if (slot == NULL) {
    9870           0 :                 PORT_SetError(SSL_ERROR_TOKEN_SLOT_NOT_FOUND);
    9871             :                 return pms; /* which is NULL */
    9872             :             }
    9873             :         }
    9874             :     }
    9875             : 
    9876             :     /* Generate the pre-master secret ...  */
    9877           0 :     if (IS_DTLS(ss)) {
    9878             :         SSL3ProtocolVersion temp;
    9879             : 
    9880           0 :         temp = dtls_TLSVersionToDTLSVersion(ss->clientHelloVersion);
    9881           0 :         version.major = MSB(temp);
    9882           0 :         version.minor = LSB(temp);
    9883             :     } else {
    9884           0 :         version.major = MSB(ss->clientHelloVersion);
    9885           0 :         version.minor = LSB(ss->clientHelloVersion);
    9886             :     }
    9887             : 
    9888           0 :     param.data = (unsigned char *)&version;
    9889           0 :     param.len = sizeof version;
    9890             : 
    9891           0 :     pms = PK11_KeyGen(slot, CKM_SSL3_PRE_MASTER_KEY_GEN, &param, 0, pwArg);
    9892           0 :     if (!serverKeySlot)
    9893           0 :         PK11_FreeSlot(slot);
    9894           0 :     if (pms == NULL) {
    9895           0 :         ssl_MapLowLevelError(SSL_ERROR_CLIENT_KEY_EXCHANGE_FAILURE);
    9896             :     }
    9897             :     return pms;
    9898             : }
    9899             : 
    9900             : /* Note: The Bleichenbacher attack on PKCS#1 necessitates that we NEVER
    9901             :  * return any indication of failure of the Client Key Exchange message,
    9902             :  * where that failure is caused by the content of the client's message.
    9903             :  * This function must not return SECFailure for any reason that is directly
    9904             :  * or indirectly caused by the content of the client's encrypted PMS.
    9905             :  * We must not send an alert and also not drop the connection.
    9906             :  * Instead, we generate a random PMS.  This will cause a failure
    9907             :  * in the processing the finished message, which is exactly where
    9908             :  * the failure must occur.
    9909             :  *
    9910             :  * Called from ssl3_HandleClientKeyExchange
    9911             :  */
    9912             : static SECStatus
    9913           0 : ssl3_HandleRSAClientKeyExchange(sslSocket *ss,
    9914             :                                 SSL3Opaque *b,
    9915             :                                 PRUint32 length,
    9916             :                                 sslKeyPair *serverKeyPair)
    9917             : {
    9918             :     SECStatus rv;
    9919             :     SECItem enc_pms;
    9920           0 :     PK11SymKey *tmpPms[2] = { NULL, NULL };
    9921             :     PK11SlotInfo *slot;
    9922           0 :     int useFauxPms = 0;
    9923             : 
    9924             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveRecvBufLock(ss));
    9925             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
    9926             :     PORT_Assert(ss->ssl3.prSpec == ss->ssl3.pwSpec);
    9927             : 
    9928           0 :     enc_pms.data = b;
    9929           0 :     enc_pms.len = length;
    9930             : 
    9931           0 :     if (ss->ssl3.prSpec->version > SSL_LIBRARY_VERSION_3_0) { /* isTLS */
    9932             :         PRUint32 kLen;
    9933           0 :         rv = ssl3_ConsumeHandshakeNumber(ss, &kLen, 2, &enc_pms.data, &enc_pms.len);
    9934           0 :         if (rv != SECSuccess) {
    9935           0 :             PORT_SetError(SSL_ERROR_CLIENT_KEY_EXCHANGE_FAILURE);
    9936           0 :             return SECFailure;
    9937             :         }
    9938           0 :         if ((unsigned)kLen < enc_pms.len) {
    9939           0 :             enc_pms.len = kLen;
    9940             :         }
    9941             :     }
    9942             : 
    9943             : #define currentPms tmpPms[!useFauxPms]
    9944             : #define unusedPms tmpPms[useFauxPms]
    9945             : #define realPms tmpPms[1]
    9946             : #define fauxPms tmpPms[0]
    9947             : 
    9948             :     /*
    9949             :      * Get as close to algorithm 2 from RFC 5246; Section 7.4.7.1
    9950             :      * as we can within the constraints of the PKCS#11 interface.
    9951             :      *
    9952             :      * 1. Unconditionally generate a bogus PMS (what RFC 5246
    9953             :      *    calls R).
    9954             :      * 2. Attempt the RSA decryption to recover the PMS (what
    9955             :      *    RFC 5246 calls M).
    9956             :      * 3. Set PMS = (M == NULL) ? R : M
    9957             :      * 4. Use ssl3_ComputeMasterSecret(PMS) to attempt to derive
    9958             :      *    the MS from PMS. This includes performing the version
    9959             :      *    check and length check.
    9960             :      * 5. If either the initial RSA decryption failed or
    9961             :      *    ssl3_ComputeMasterSecret(PMS) failed, then discard
    9962             :      *    M and set PMS = R. Else, discard R and set PMS = M.
    9963             :      *
    9964             :      * We do two derivations here because we can't rely on having
    9965             :      * a function that only performs the PMS version and length
    9966             :      * check. The only redundant cost is that this runs the PRF,
    9967             :      * which isn't necessary here.
    9968             :      */
    9969             : 
    9970             :     /* Generate the bogus PMS (R) */
    9971           0 :     slot = PK11_GetSlotFromPrivateKey(serverKeyPair->privKey);
    9972           0 :     if (!slot) {
    9973           0 :         PORT_SetError(SEC_ERROR_LIBRARY_FAILURE);
    9974             :         return SECFailure;
    9975             :     }
    9976             : 
    9977           0 :     if (!PK11_DoesMechanism(slot, CKM_SSL3_MASTER_KEY_DERIVE)) {
    9978           0 :         PK11_FreeSlot(slot);
    9979           0 :         slot = PK11_GetBestSlot(CKM_SSL3_MASTER_KEY_DERIVE, NULL);
    9980           0 :         if (!slot) {
    9981           0 :             PORT_SetError(SEC_ERROR_LIBRARY_FAILURE);
    9982             :             return SECFailure;
    9983             :         }
    9984             :     }
    9985             : 
    9986           0 :     ssl_GetSpecWriteLock(ss);
    9987           0 :     fauxPms = ssl3_GenerateRSAPMS(ss, ss->ssl3.prSpec, slot);
    9988           0 :     ssl_ReleaseSpecWriteLock(ss);

   11610             :     /* RFC 5077 Section 3.3: "The client MUST NOT treat the ticket as valid
   11611             :      * until it has verified the server's Finished message." When the server

   11613             :      * the handshake is finished (we have verified the server's Finished
   11614             :      * AND the server's certificate) before we update the ticket in the sid.
   11615             :      *

   11936             :

   11938             : }
   11939             : 
   11940             : /* Called only from ssl3_HandleRecord, for each (deciphered) ssl3 record.
   11941             :  * origBuf is the decrypted ssl record content.
   11942             :  * Caller must hold the handshake and RecvBuf locks.
   11943             :  */
   11944             : static SECStatus
   11945           1 : ssl3_HandleHandshake(sslSocket *ss, sslBuffer *origBuf)
   11946             : {
   11947             :     /*
   11948             :      * There may be a partial handshake message already in the handshake
   11949             :      * state. The incoming buffer may contain another portion, or a
   11950             :      * complete message or several messages followed by another portion.
   11951             :      *
   11952             :      * Each message is made contiguous before being passed to the actual
   11953             :      * message parser.
   11954             :      */
   11955           1 :     sslBuffer *buf = &ss->ssl3.hs.msgState; /* do not lose the original buffer pointer */
   11956             :     SECStatus rv;
   11957             : 
   11958             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveRecvBufLock(ss));
   11959             :     PORT_Assert(ss->opt.noLocks || ssl_HaveSSL3HandshakeLock(ss));
   11960             : 
   11961           1 :     if (buf->buf == NULL) {
   11962           1 :         *buf = *origBuf;
   11963             :     }
   11964           1 :     while (buf->len > 0) {
   11965           1 :         if (ss->ssl3.hs.header_bytes < 4) {
   11966             :             PRUint8 t;

   11975             :

   11985             :             ** even if buf->len is zero.

   11988           1 :                 continue;
   11989             :         }

   11991             :         /*

   12064             : }
   12065             : 
   12066             : /* These macros return the given value with the MSB copied to all the other
   12067             :  * bits. They use the fact that arithmetic shift shifts-in the sign bit.
   12068             :  * However, this is not ensured by the C standard so you may need to replace
   12069             :  * them with something else for odd compilers. */
   12070             : #define DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(x) ((unsigned)((int)(x) >> (sizeof(int) * 8 - 1)))
   12071             : #define DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL_8(x) ((unsigned char)(DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(x)))
   12072             : 
   12073             : /* SECStatusToMask returns, in constant time, a mask value of all ones if
   12074             :  * rv == SECSuccess.  Otherwise it returns zero. */
   12075             : static unsigned int
   12076             : SECStatusToMask(SECStatus rv)
   12077             : {
   12078             :     unsigned int good;
   12079             :     /* rv ^ SECSuccess is zero iff rv == SECSuccess. Subtracting one results
   12080             :      * in the MSB being set to one iff it was zero before. */
   12081           1 :     good = rv ^ SECSuccess;
   12082           1 :     good--;
   12083           1 :     return DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(good);
   12084             : }
   12085             : 
   12086             : /* ssl_ConstantTimeGE returns 0xff if a>=b and 0x00 otherwise. */
   12087             : static unsigned char
   12088             : ssl_ConstantTimeGE(unsigned int a, unsigned int b)
   12089             : {
   12090           1 :     a -= b;
   12091           1 :     return DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(~a);
   12092             : }
   12093             : 
   12094             : /* ssl_ConstantTimeEQ8 returns 0xff if a==b and 0x00 otherwise. */
   12095             : static unsigned char
   12096             : ssl_ConstantTimeEQ8(unsigned char a, unsigned char b)
   12097             : {
   12098           1 :     unsigned int c = a ^ b;
   12099           1 :     c--;
   12100           1 :     return DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL_8(c);
   12101             : }
   12102             : 
   12103             : /* ssl_constantTimeSelect return a if mask is 0xFF and b if mask is 0x00 */
   12104             : static unsigned char
   12105             : ssl_constantTimeSelect(unsigned char mask, unsigned char a, unsigned char b)
   12106             : {
   12107           1 :     return (mask & a) | (~mask & b);
   12108             : }
   12109             : 
   12110             : static SECStatus
   12111           0 : ssl_RemoveSSLv3CBCPadding(sslBuffer *plaintext,
   12112             :                           unsigned int blockSize,
   12113             :                           unsigned int macSize)
   12114             : {
   12115             :     unsigned int paddingLength, good, t;
   12116           0 :     const unsigned int overhead = 1 /* padding length byte */ + macSize;
   12117             : 
   12118             :     /* These lengths are all public so we can test them in non-constant
   12119             :      * time. */
   12120           0 :     if (overhead > plaintext->len) {
   12121             :         return SECFailure;
   12122             :     }
   12123             : 
   12124           0 :     paddingLength = plaintext->buf[plaintext->len - 1];
   12125             :     /* SSLv3 padding bytes are random and cannot be checked. */
   12126           0 :     t = plaintext->len;
   12127           0 :     t -= paddingLength + overhead;
   12128             :     /* If len >= paddingLength+overhead then the MSB of t is zero. */
   12129           0 :     good = DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(~t);
   12130             :     /* SSLv3 requires that the padding is minimal. */
   12131           0 :     t = blockSize - (paddingLength + 1);
   12132           0 :     good &= DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(~t);

   12135             : }

   12137             : SECStatus
   12138           1 : ssl_RemoveTLSCBCPadding(sslBuffer *plaintext, unsigned int macSize)
   12139             : {
   12140             :     unsigned int paddingLength, good, t, toCheck, i;
   12141           1 :     const unsigned int overhead = 1 /* padding length byte */ + macSize;
   12142             : 
   12143             :     /* These lengths are all public so we can test them in non-constant
   12144             :      * time. */
   12145           1 :     if (overhead > plaintext->len) {
   12146             :         return SECFailure;
   12147             :     }
   12148             : 
   12149           1 :     paddingLength = plaintext->buf[plaintext->len - 1];
   12150           1 :     t = plaintext->len;
   12151           1 :     t -= paddingLength + overhead;
   12152             :     /* If len >= paddingLength+overhead then the MSB of t is zero. */
   12153           1 :     good = DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(~t);
   12154             : 
   12155             :     /* The padding consists of a length byte at the end of the record and then
   12156             :      * that many bytes of padding, all with the same value as the length byte.
   12157             :      * Thus, with the length byte included, there are paddingLength+1 bytes of
   12158             :      * padding.
   12159             :      *
   12160             :      * We can't check just |paddingLength+1| bytes because that leaks
   12161             :      * decrypted information. Therefore we always have to check the maximum
   12162             :      * amount of padding possible. (Again, the length of the record is
   12163             :      * public information so we can use it.) */
   12164           1 :     toCheck = 256; /* maximum amount of padding + 1. */
   12165           1 :     if (toCheck > plaintext->len) {
   12166           1 :         toCheck = plaintext->len;
   12167             :     }
   12168             : 
   12169           1 :     for (i = 0; i < toCheck; i++) {
   12170           1 :         unsigned int t = paddingLength - i;
   12171             :         /* If i <= paddingLength then the MSB of t is zero and mask is
   12172             :          * 0xff.  Otherwise, mask is 0. */
   12173           1 :         unsigned char mask = DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(~t);
   12174           1 :         unsigned char b = plaintext->buf[plaintext->len - 1 - i];
   12175             :         /* The final |paddingLength+1| bytes should all have the value
   12176             :          * |paddingLength|. Therefore the XOR should be zero. */
   12177           1 :         good &= ~(mask & (paddingLength ^ b));
   12178             :     }
   12179             : 
   12180             :     /* If any of the final |paddingLength+1| bytes had the wrong value,
   12181             :      * one or more of the lower eight bits of |good| will be cleared. We
   12182             :      * AND the bottom 8 bits together and duplicate the result to all the
   12183             :      * bits. */
   12184           1 :     good &= good >> 4;
   12185           1 :     good &= good >> 2;
   12186           1 :     good &= good >> 1;
   12187           1 :     good <<= sizeof(good) * 8 - 1;
   12188           1 :     good = DUPLICATE_MSB_TO_ALL(good);
   12189             : 
   12190           1 :     plaintext->len -= good & (paddingLength + 1);
   12191           1 :     return (good & SECSuccess) | (~good & SECFailure);
   12192             : }
   12193             : 
   12194             : /* On entry:
   12195             :  *   originalLength >= macSize
   12196             :  *   macSize <= MAX_MAC_LENGTH
   12197             :  *   plaintext->len >= macSize
   12198             :  */
   12199             : static void
   12200           1 : ssl_CBCExtractMAC(sslBuffer *plaintext,
   12201             :                   unsigned int originalLength,
   12202             :                   SSL3Opaque *out,
   12203             :                   unsigned int macSize)
   12204             : {
   12205             :     unsigned char rotatedMac[MAX_MAC_LENGTH];
   12206             :     /* macEnd is the index of |plaintext->buf| just after the end of the
   12207             :      * MAC. */
   12208           1 :     unsigned macEnd = plaintext->len;
   12209           1 :     unsigned macStart = macEnd - macSize;
   12210             :     /* scanStart contains the number of bytes that we can ignore because
   12211             :      * the MAC's position can only vary by 255 bytes. */
   12212           1 :     unsigned scanStart = 0;
   12213             :     unsigned i, j;
   12214             :     unsigned char rotateOffset;
   12215             : 
   12216           1 :     if (originalLength > macSize + 255 + 1) {
   12217           1 :         scanStart = originalLength - (macSize + 255 + 1);
   12218             :     }
   12219             : 
   12220             :     /* We want to compute
   12221             :      * rotateOffset = (macStart - scanStart) % macSize
   12222             :      * But the time to compute this varies based on the amount of padding. Thus
   12223             :      * we explicitely handle all mac sizes with (hopefully) constant time modulo
   12224             :      * using Barrett reduction:
   12225             :      *  q := (rotateOffset * m) >> k
   12226             :      *  rotateOffset -= q * n
   12227             :      *  if (n <= rotateOffset) rotateOffset -= n
   12228             :      */
   12229           1 :     rotateOffset = macStart - scanStart;
   12230             :     /* rotateOffset < 255 + 1 + 48 = 304 */
   12231           1 :     if (macSize == 16) {
   12232           0 :         rotateOffset &= 15;
   12233           1 :     } else if (macSize == 20) {
   12234             :         /*
   12235             :          * Correctness: rotateOffset * ( 1/20 - 25/2^9 ) < 1
   12236             :          *              with rotateOffset <= 853
   12237             :          */
   12238           1 :         unsigned q = (rotateOffset * 25) >> 9;
   12239           1 :         rotateOffset -= q * 20;
   12240           1 :         rotateOffset -= ssl_constantTimeSelect(ssl_ConstantTimeGE(rotateOffset, 20),
   12241             :                                                20, 0);
   12242           0 :     } else if (macSize == 32) {
   12243           0 :         rotateOffset &= 31;
   12244           0 :     } else if (macSize == 48) {
   12245             :         /*
   12246             :          * Correctness: rotateOffset * ( 1/48 - 10/2^9 ) < 1
   12247             :          *              with rotateOffset < 768
   12248             :          */
   12249           0 :         unsigned q = (rotateOffset * 10) >> 9;
   12250           0 :         rotateOffset -= q * 48;
   12251           0 :         rotateOffset -= ssl_constantTimeSelect(ssl_ConstantTimeGE(rotateOffset, 48),
   12252             :                                                48, 0);
   12253             :     } else {
   12254             :         /*
   12255             :          * SHA384 (macSize == 48) is the largest we support. We should never
   12256             :          * get here.
   12257             :          */
   12258             :         PORT_Assert(0);
   12259           0 :         rotateOffset = rotateOffset % macSize;
   12260             :     }
   12261             : 
   12262           1 :     memset(rotatedMac, 0, macSize);
   12263           1 :     for (i = scanStart; i < originalLength;) {
   12264           1 :         for (j = 0; j < macSize && i < originalLength; i++, j++) {
   12265           1 :             unsigned char macStarted = ssl_ConstantTimeGE(i, macStart);
   12266           1 :             unsigned char macEnded = ssl_ConstantTimeGE(i, macEnd);
   12267           1 :             unsigned char b = 0;
   12268           1 :             b = plaintext->buf[i];
   12269           1 :             rotatedMac[j] |= b & macStarted & ~macEnded;
   12270             :         }
   12271             :     }
   12272             : 
   12273             :     /* Now rotate the MAC. If we knew that the MAC fit into a CPU cache line
   12274             :      * we could line-align |rotatedMac| and rotate in place. */
   12275           1 :     memset(out, 0, macSize);
   12276           1 :     rotateOffset = macSize - rotateOffset;
   12277           1 :     rotateOffset = ssl_constantTimeSelect(ssl_ConstantTimeGE(rotateOffset, macSize),
   12278             :                                           0, rotateOffset);
   12279           1 :     for (i = 0; i < macSize; i++) {
   12280           1 :         for (j = 0; j < macSize; j++) {
   12281           1 :             out[j] |= rotatedMac[i] & ssl_ConstantTimeEQ8(j, rotateOffset);
   12282             :         }
   12283           1 :         rotateOffset++;
   12284           1 :         rotateOffset = ssl_constantTimeSelect(ssl_ConstantTimeGE(rotateOffset, macSize),
   12285             :                                               0, rotateOffset);
   12286             :     }
   12287           1 : }
   12288             : 
   12289             : /* Unprotect an SSL3 record and leave the result in plaintext.
   12290             :  *
   12291             :  * If SECFailure is returned, we:
   12292             :  * 1. Set |*alert| to the alert to be sent.
   12293             :  * 2. Call PORT_SetError() with an appropriate code.
   12294             :  *
   12295             :  * Called by ssl3_HandleRecord. Caller must hold the spec read lock.
   12296             :  * Therefore, we MUST not call SSL3_SendAlert().
   12297             :  *
   12298             :  */
   12299             : static SECStatus
   12300           1 : ssl3_UnprotectRecord(sslSocket *ss, SSL3Ciphertext *cText, sslBuffer *plaintext,
   12301             :                      SSL3AlertDescription *alert)
   12302             : {
   12303           1 :     ssl3CipherSpec *crSpec = ss->ssl3.crSpec;
   12304           1 :     const ssl3BulkCipherDef *cipher_def = crSpec->cipher_def;
   12305             :     PRBool isTLS;
   12306             :     unsigned int good;
   12307           1 :     unsigned int ivLen = 0;
   12308             :     SSL3ContentType rType;
   12309             :     unsigned int minLength;
   12310           1 :     unsigned int originalLen = 0;
   12311             :     unsigned char header[13];
   12312             :     unsigned int headerLen;
   12313             :     SSL3Opaque hash[MAX_MAC_LENGTH];
   12314             :     SSL3Opaque givenHashBuf[MAX_MAC_LENGTH];
   12315             :     SSL3Opaque *givenHash;
   12316           1 :     unsigned int hashBytes = MAX_MAC_LENGTH + 1;
   12317             :     SECStatus rv;
   12318             : 
   12319           1 :     good = ~0U;
   12320           1 :     minLength = crSpec->mac_size;
   12321           1 :     if (cipher_def->type == type_block) {
   12322             :         /* CBC records have a padding length byte at the end. */
   12323           1 :         minLength++;
   12324           1 :         if (crSpec->version >= SSL_LIBRARY_VERSION_TLS_1_1) {
   12325             :             /* With >= TLS 1.1, CBC records have an explicit IV. */
   12326           0 :             minLength += cipher_def->iv_size;
   12327             :         }
   12328           1 :     } else if (cipher_def->type == type_aead) {
   12329           1 :         minLength = cipher_def->explicit_nonce_size + cipher_def->tag_size;
   12330             :     }
   12331             : 
   12332             :     /* We can perform this test in variable time because the record's total
   12333             :      * length and the ciphersuite are both public knowledge. */
   12334           1 :     if (cText->buf->len < minLength) {
   12335             :         goto decrypt_loser;
   12336             :     }

   12489             : /* if cText is non-null, then decipher, check MAC, and decompress the
   12490             :  * SSL record from cText->buf (typically gs->inbuf)
   12491             :  * into databuf (typically gs->buf), and any previous contents of databuf
   12492             :  * is lost.  Then handle databuf according to its SSL record type,
   12493             :  * unless it's an application record.
   12494             :  *
   12495             :  * If cText is NULL, then the ciphertext has previously been deciphered and

   13144             : 
   13145             : /*
   13146             : ** If ssl3 socket has completed the first handshake, and is in idle state,
   13147             : ** then start a new handshake.
   13148             : ** If flushCache is true, the SID cache will be flushed first, forcing a
   13149             : ** "Full" handshake (not a session restart handshake), to be done.
   13150             : **
   13151             : ** called from SSL_RedoHandshake(), which already holds the handshake locks.
   13152             : */
   13153             : SECStatus
   13154           0 : ssl3_RedoHandshake(sslSocket *ss, PRBool flushCache)

   13164           0 :         return SECFailure;
   13165             :     }
   13166             : 
   13167           0 :     if (IS_DTLS(ss)) {
   13168           0 :         dtls_RehandshakeCleanup(ss);

   13171           0 :     if (ss->opt.enableRenegotiation == SSL_RENEGOTIATE_NEVER ||

   13173           0 :         PORT_SetError(SSL_ERROR_RENEGOTIATION_NOT_ALLOWED);
   13174           0 :         return SECFailure;
   13175             :     }
   13176           0 :     if (sid && flushCache) {
   13177           0 :         ss->sec.uncache(sid); /* remove it from whichever cache it's in. */

   13179           0 :         ss->sec.ci.sid = NULL;
   13180             :     }
   13181             : 
   13182           0 :     ssl_GetXmitBufLock(ss); /**************************************/
   13183             : 
   13184             :     /* start off a new handshake. */
   13185           0 :     if (ss->sec.isServer) {
   13186           0 :         rv = ssl3_SendHelloRequest(ss);
